moves.3. exd5 cxd5 4. d4 Bf5: a6 could be better before this move.
moves.5. Bb5+ Nc6 6. Ne5 Bd7: White attacks and have time for developing, as black cannot breath.
moves.7. Nxd7: White makes it easier for black. The change of attacking figures is worse, then developing.
moves.7... Qxd7 8. Nc3 e6: Without the white bishop I try to defence the white squares, make place for the kingside developing.
moves.9. O-O a6 10. Bd3 Nxd4 11. Bxh7: I was oversee this, but not so bad, because I wasnot castled yet, so white gives me a half-opened file against its king. So good as bad.
moves.11... Rxh7 12. Qxd4 Bd6: I try to make a pressure on h2.
moves.13. h3 Ne7 14. Qd3 Ng6 15. Ne2 O-O-O: White takes his knight away from the queenside, so I castled there and doubling the rooks on the h-file. My pieces will be active, whites' bishop and rook stands on the original places.
moves.16. Nf4: Good Idea! After the exchanges my rook is lost on h7.
moves.16... Bxf4 17. Bxf4 Rdh8: Forcing the attack and the bishop on f4 hanging now.
moves.18. Bg3: Could be better on h2, so the queen is isolated from the h3 pawn.
After gxh3, black can maybe make an ever-check, but it isnot sure. After the e5 push I tried attack without mind and waited for a blunder from white because of the pressure.
moves.27. Reg1 Qh3 28. Ke1: After ...Qf1 Gg3  would push away the king and after the exchanges on h2 falls down the b2 pawn - otherwise the rook is lost on c1.
